title: Shanghai rocket maker considering developing huge methane-fueled rockets
summary: A major arm of China’s state-owned space contractor is looking at developing a series of partially and fully-reusable launch vehicles apparently in response to SpaceX’s Starship.

title: NASA requests proposal for second Artemis crewed lunar lander
summary: NASA has released a request for proposals for a second human lunar lander for the Artemis program to join the Starship lander under development by SpaceX.

title: New tri-agency office to coordinate U.S. missile-defense space programs
summary: The Space Systems Command, the Space Development Agency and the Missile Defense Agency have formed a new program office to coordinate disparate procurements of satellites to detect ballistic and hypersonic missiles.

title: NASA Sets TV Coverage for Crewed Soyuz Mission to Space Station
summary: NASA will provide live coverage of key events as a NASA astronaut and two cosmonauts launch and dock to the International Space Station on Wednesday, Sept. 21.

title: NASA Pursues Astronaut Lunar Landers for Future Artemis Moon Missions
summary: NASA is seeking proposals for sustainable lunar lander development and demonstration as the agency works toward a regular cadence of Moon landings.

title: NASA to Televise Artemis I Demonstration Test, Host Media Call
summary: NASA will provide live coverage with commentary of the upcoming Artemis I cryogenic demonstration test beginning at 7:15 a.m. EDT on Wednesday, Sept. 21.

title: SpaceX and NASA in final preparations for Crew-5 mission
summary: With the launch just weeks away, SpaceX, NASA, and their international partners are in final preparations for the fifth operational Crew Dragon mission. As part of NASA’s Commercial Crew Program (CCP), Crew-5 will be SpaceX’s fifth long-duration crew mission, eighth overall crewed mission, and the first mission with a Russian Cosmonaut.

title: Viasat’s Inmarsat acquisition clears UK national security review
summary: Viasat took a step closer to buying London-based Inmarsat Sept. 16 after the British government ruled it poses no risk to the U.K.’s national security.

title: Satellite radar startups spar over commercial market importance
summary: Satellite radar startups disagree over how much of their resources should be moved to meet anticipated demand from commercial customers and away from governments, which today provide the bulk of revenues.

title: In a bid to expand its Moon business, Intuitive Machines will go public
summary: "This really gives the financial resources to take the next steps."
